video.title: Maths for Programmers: Sets (DeMorgan’s Law)
video.description:
We're busy people who learn to code, then practice by building projects for nonprofits. Learn Full-stack JavaScript, build a portfolio, and get great references with our open source community.

Join our community at https://freecodecamp.com
Follow us on twitter: https://twitter.com/freecodecamp
Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/freecodecamp
Follow Quincy on Quora: https://www.quora.com/Quincy-Larson

topLevelComment.author: NoelBahThis
topLevelComment.text: 1:11 isnt "union" suppose to be broken into "or"??

topLevelComment.author: Shiva N
topLevelComment.text:
Mistake at 01:11 and 01:17 , such that correct pronunciation is as follows,
01:11
X is element of A's complement and X is element of B's complement.
01:17
X is element of A's complement intersection B's complement.

topLevelComment.author: Fredo Corleone
topLevelComment.text: Why is this even useful in practical everyday life of a programmer?

replies.author: Johny Wuijts
replies.text: @Tepung Goreng it might me useful for regex

replies.author: Tepung Goreng
replies.text: Do you manage to get this answer yet?

topLevelComment.author: Saurabh Chaturvedi
topLevelComment.text: You're wrong around 1:11. By definition, x is an element of A complement.
way above my head. i gotta relearn the basics or something lol

replies.author: Iain Diamond
replies.text: I found reading through some Boolean algebra examples that apply De Morgan's Law quite helpful: http://theteacher.info/index.php/programming-development-1/2-logical-operations/all-topics/3614-simplifying-statements-in-boolean-algebra-using-de-morgan-s-laws
